channel.title: Alex Wilson's writing
channel.description: Alex on engineering, products & everything in-between

item.title: Weeknotes: Gold-ish — Week 19, 2025
item.description: This week was one I that have been dreading for a decade. Firstly and most importantly, yes, the rumours are true. I did buy a microwave with a flat-folding door. It doubles as an oven and came with the cutest little…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This week was one I that have been dreading for a decade.
  • Firstly and most importantly, yes, the rumours are true. I did buy a microwave with a flat-folding door. It doubles as an oven and came with the cutest little baking tray, perfect for the sourdough baking obsession which the stats say is likely heading my way in the next few years.
  • My ambitious-yet-still-approval-seeking younger self set high expectations for where I would be, who I would be and what I would have done by the time this week came around. And more recently, since the close brush at the start of ’23, there have been times when I thought that I might not see this week. But here we are. We did it. This week I turned 30. And, consequentially, I no longer qualify for a UK rail card.
  • In the end I'm not really sure what all the fuss was about.
  • Golden Week, or "GW", is four bank holidays which normally create an entire week of downtime. This year two of them were at weekend. Back home, when a bank holiday occurs on a Saturday or Sunday, the next available weekday becomes a substitute holiday. So consecutive days become consecutive holidays. Japan has a similar rule, but only for Sundays. Meaning that this year’s Golden Week was really more of a “Gold-ish-Monday…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Robotic Cat — Week 18, 2025
item.description: Another month, another ward office trip. This time it’s Chiyoda, and instead of having translated forms, they have actual interpreters. The hardest part is writing out kanji. Done and done in record time. This week we go…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Another month, another ward office trip. This time it’s Chiyoda, and instead of having translated forms, they have actual interpreters. The hardest part is writing out kanji. Done and done in record time.
  • This week we go to war. In my new bathroom, there is a smell which I can’t identify, locate or label. It’s not an unpleasant smell, but, it’s definitely not a pleasant one either. It smells a lot like soap, but, sweet? Research and conversations suggest that it’s the product of a “bio-film”, which is a brand new type of home maintenance problem that I’d rather not have learned about. I steadily arm myself with every category of cleaning product.
  • Wrapping Monday I run (literally) from work in the pouring rain to see US, one of my favourite all-time people who is in town for one night and one night only. Over reasonably-priced yakiniku we talk bikes and the expo in a room which — by medium of sharpie — very loudly shares my politics.
  • Okonomiyaki in Sumida-city is lots of fun, but…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Candle — Week 17, 2025
item.description: When leaving the UK, I got a lot of advice. One bit stood out above the rest. “Find somewhere to live which reminds you that you’re in Japan”. This week I moved into that place. It’s within spitting distance of a…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• When leaving the UK, I got a lot of advice. One bit stood out above the rest. “Find somewhere to live which reminds you that you’re in Japan”. This week I moved into that place. It’s within spitting distance of a centroid and from my window I can just about see the NTT Docomo Yoyogi building.
  • There was some work stuff too this week, but I’ll spare you.
  • The actual move was very, very easy. Faster than last time. The hard part was actually cleaning my last apartment (by my count, making it the third time this year!).
  • I'll miss living in Azabu though. It made me nostalgic for my flat in Sofia.
  • Only trouble with moving in for the first time, during peak moving season, is that I own no furniture. Zip. Nothing. Nada.
  • So anyway, I’m temporarily sleeping on AB’s old futon.
  • Bought some essentials: Blinds, towels, kettle and a hair dryer which looks & sounds like a Dyson Supersonic but definitely isn’t.
  • Some reprieve at a Sushiro dinner (which was considerably more reasonably priced…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Eggs — Week 16, 2025
item.description: This was a cyclical week. Went to Microsoft HQ for hands-on training with Azure AI services. There I built a tool for getting answers from a large collection of technical documentation. It comprised a processing…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This was a cyclical week.
  • Went to Microsoft HQ for hands-on training with Azure AI services. There I built a tool for getting answers from a large collection of technical documentation. It comprised a processing pipeline and an agent, and because I have trust issues, I extended it to issue citations.
  • This actually blew my mind. A few years and a few teams ago, I worked on a similar problem so I’m familiar with the NLP problem space: Long months of experimentation were reduced to a few keystrokes and clicks over an afternoon. The commodification of tooling right now is impressive, and I walked out shocked.
  • Shipped the largest codebase change I’ve made recently affecting 364 files, which required a few weeks of lead-in and planning. OMG I'm so relieved it’s over.
  • Went for dinner with some folks working data where we talked news and I tried my very very best to sell the UK and London as places to at least visit. Unfortunately recent headlines about Birmingham made it impossible to sell going there. C’mon people, how else are we getting people to visit PureCraft…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Flowering — Week 13, 2025
item.description: Cherry blossom season is upon us, and it’s gorgeous. The parks are chokka. Unfortunately the same cannot be said of the weather: It has been cold, and dark, and damp, and miserable all week. Between the weather and…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Cherry blossom season is upon us, and it’s gorgeous. The parks are chokka. Unfortunately the same cannot be said of the weather: It has been cold, and dark, and damp, and miserable all week.
  • Between the weather and immediately jumping back into work, even though it was a few days, I was suffering a proper holiday hangover this week.
  • Many years ago I read “Working Effectively with Legacy Code”, and it excited me to work with gnarly codebases. Well, let’s just say I burned a lot of that excitement this week.
  • After missing 3 lessons in a row, Japanese class was incredibly rough. We made it, in the end, but wow there were moments where I doubted myself. Who’d have guessed that learning a language is hard.
  • Very thought provoking catch-up on Wednesday evening. 😅
  • Had a university final during the week. It caught me by surprise, but luckily it was in an area I know well. Finished with hours to spare.
  • Omiyage of sweetheart cake (老婆餅) was very well received. I had a spare which I stuck…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Sharp Sandspit — Week 12, 2025
item.description: If last week marked my first serious travel since the big move, this week marked my proper first holiday - and with it, more travel. Thursday was a bank holiday and together with Friday made for an extended “long…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• If last week marked my first serious travel since the big move, this week marked my proper first holiday - and with it, more travel. Thursday was a bank holiday and together with Friday made for an extended “long weekend”.

  • This week in data:

    • Maximum height: 332.6m
    • Kowloon Dairy products consumed: 7

  • After work on Tuesday evening I went to the top of Landmark 81 - the tallest building in Vietnam, the 2nd tallest in SEA and the 17th tallest in the world. It is also, by at least 100 meters, the highest I have ever been. Reaching the top, they strapped me to a pole and let me walk right up to the edge, where I took a few precarious photos and a selfie, right before scurrying right back down to ground level. Gorgeous view though, well worth the nerves.

  • Wrestled with some NodeJS meta-programming which I really didn't enjoy. Sometimes I think we had it good with n-gage.

  • And on Wednesday, REDACTED. All I’m saying.

  • On Thursday I packed up, picked up some laundry, had some emergency banh mi, and swatted away the biggest cockroach you ever did see, before collapsing into an airplane seat. Onboard I watched The Apprentice (2024), which I really rate, it’s a very good movie. Solid 3/5.

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Thanh — Week 11, 2025
item.description: This week was spent in Ho Chi Minh City 🇻🇳 for both a business trip, and my first trip outside of Tokyo since the big move. This week in data: 🌞 Average temperature: 31°C 🌫️ Average humidity 67.36% 🤢 Cockroaches…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This week was spent in Ho Chi Minh City 🇻🇳 for both a business trip, and my first trip outside of Tokyo since the big move.

  • This week in data:

    • 🌞 Average temperature: 31°C
    • 🌫️ Average humidity 67.36%
    • 🤢 Cockroaches spotted: 34

  • Monday begins mega early in Narita and possibly the slowest airport check in I’ve ever done. Nearly an hour. Thankfully the rest of the journey to the gate was speedy, but, reader, I’d be lying if I didn’t say that this felt mega dicey.

  • Immediately on landing I’m struck by the heat. It’s hot. It’s so hot that every minute feels like five. By the time we get to a taxi my brain has nearly adjusted.

  • Our first meal is Phở at a local place, and it ends up being one of the tastiest meals of the week as well as due to my choice of toppings probably the least healthy. We get oodles of free vegetables which - coming from Tokyo - is amazing.

  • Bikes. Bikes everywhere.

  • With many of us colocated in the same space for the first time in a while, we ran through lots of workshops ranging from talking about our backgrounds to experiencing what it’s like for users to use one of our products. Great energy all around and I enjoyed the time with people I don’t normally work with.

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Searching — Week 10, 2025
item.description: Hello from Narita. I took three trains and a bus to get here — normally it’s only one train — so, not in a great mood. Hopefully tomorrow’s breakfast will make the journey worth it! With next week being my first real…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Hello from Narita. I took three trains and a bus to get here — normally it’s only one train — so, not in a great mood. Hopefully tomorrow’s breakfast will make the journey worth it!
  • With next week being my first real travel since moving to Japan, this week was all about working through a shopping list and a todo list of preparation.
  • It snowed on Tuesday! Proper snow! In March! I don’t even own snow boots anymore!
  • Prepping a workshop for next week really didn’t take long. Finding the right brand of insect spray, surprisingly, did.
  • For lack of having the ingredients, to celebrate Pancake Day I bought some premade pancakes, some honey and some sour cream. It wasn’t until too late in the process that I realised I’d made glorified doriyaki, reader, but damn were they good.
  • Still running!
  • Is it me or is there a secret second last train which doesn’t appear on the train timetable, immediately after the last train? It’s either that or I believed a bunch of ghosts.
  • The phrase “cost…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Deepening — Week 09, 2025
item.description: This was the week when I tried every single commodity LLM, and a few other things we’re labelling “AI”. And let me tell you, oh boy have my opinions on AI flip-flopped like the integrity of a career politician. More on…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This was the week when I tried every single commodity LLM, and a few other things we’re labelling “AI”. And let me tell you, oh boy have my opinions on AI flip-flopped like the integrity of a career politician. More on that after the break.

  • This week in data:

    • Papers read: 3
    • Distance run: 13.29km
    • Gigs attended: 1

  • To put it mildly, it really hasn’t been a good week from a current affairs perspective. On Thursday I started writing a message to someone and by the time I sent it on Sunday I had to redraft it, twice.

  • This has been a good week for paperwork on Planet Alex. I signed the lease for my long-term apartment this week, which was a much more involved process than any other contract signing I’ve ever done, including the ones through [name of a random previous employer]’s procurement system. 10 sheets of A3 paper. My wonderful agent even had a pen and a bottle of water ready for my troubles. If anyone is looking for property in Tokyo, I will definitely connect you, please ask.

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Boxes — Week 8, 2025
item.description: Headline this week is that I moved at the weekend. Goodbye Shibaura and hello Azabu. It’s a considerably different experience: Some streets round here don't feel like Tokyo. And amongst other things, I traded a work…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Headline this week is that I moved at the weekend. Goodbye Shibaura and hello Azabu. It’s a considerably different experience: Some streets round here don't feel like Tokyo. And amongst other things, I traded a work desk for a dining table. I haven’t had a dining table since August 2021. Now my breakfasts feel somehow dignified.

  • This week in data:

    • Papers read: 0
    • Distance run: 10.82km
    • Gigs attended: 0

  • Class is going well. We formally began the Kanji. At some point I have learned to handwrite most of the katakana and hiragana. And at Tuesday lunchtime I managed to order in a non-English-speaking restaurant without any aids, and it didn’t seem very awkward.

  • Second month in a row that I’m deep-cleaning a flat. This one was a bit easier at least: Three months is a lot less than four years.

  • MA helped me move by renting a van and helping me shift 3 bags, 2 suitcases and 1 box all in one go. This was by far the easiest inter-city move I’ve ever done — the hard part was sourcing the bags — and I hope the next one goes just as smoothly.

    …

Read the full post here...
